If $f(x)=c$, a constant, for all $x$, we must have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& c=c(1+c) \\
& c=c+c^{2} \\
& 0=c^{2} \\
& 0=c,
\end{aligned}
$$

and the solution $f(x)=0$ has already been noted. Thus we may assume that $f$ is not a constant.

Plugging $y=-1$ into (3) gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x(1-1)) & =f(x)(1+f(-1)) \\
f(0) & =f(x)(1+f(-1))
\end{aligned}
$$

If $f(-1) \neq-1$, we have $f(x)=\frac{f(0)}{1+f(-1)}$, a constant. Thus we may assume that $f(-1)=-1$. It follows that $f(0)=0$. Next we try to find $u:=f(1)$. Plugging $x=1$ and $y=-2$ into (3) gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(1(1-2)) & =f(1)(1+f(-2)) \\
f(-1) & =f(1)(1+f(-2)) \\
-1 & =u(1+f(-2)) .
\end{aligned}
$$

On the other hand, with $x=-1$ and $y=1$ in (3), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(-(1+1)) & =f(-1)(1+f(1)) \\
f(-2) & =-(1+u)
\end{aligned}
$$

and plugging this into (4),

$$
\begin{aligned}
-1 & =u(1-(1-u)) \\
& =u(-u) \\
1 & =u^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

so $u=1$ or $u=-1$. If $u=-1$, using $y=1$ in (3) yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x(1+1)) & =f(x)(1+f(1)) \\
f(2 x) & =f(x)(1-1)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

and $f$ becomes a constant. Thus we must have $f(1)=1$. Using $x=1$ in (3),

$$
f(1+y)=f(1)(1+f(y))=1+f(y) \text {. }
$$

We can use this identity to transform (3):

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x(1+y)) & =f(x)(1+f(y)) \\
& =f(x) f(1+y)
\end{aligned}
$$

and letting $z=1+y$, we get

$$
f(x z)=f(x) f(z)
$$

for all $x$ and $z$. Now we transform (3) in yet another way:

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(x(1+y)) & =f(x)(1+f(y)) \\
f(x+x y) & =f(x)+f(x) f(y) \\
& =f(x)+f(x y)
\end{aligned}
$$

letting $z=x y$,

$$
f(x+z)=f(x)+f(z)
$$

whenever $x \neq 0$. Since this equation is trivially true when $x=0$, we can use it for all $x$ and $z$. Repeatedly applying it to the known values $f(1)=1, f(-1)=-1$, we find $f(x)=x$ whenever $x$ is an integer. Then, if $\frac{m}{n}$ is any rational number, plugging $x=\frac{m}{n}, z=n$ into (5) shows that $f(x)=x$ for rational $x$ as well. Setting $x=y$ in (5) gives

$$
f\left(x^{2}\right)=(f(x))^{2},
$$

so if $x$ is nonnegative, so is $f(x)$. By (6), if $x \geq y$, then $f(x) \geq f(y)$. Suppose that $f(a)>a$ for some irrational $a$. Then there is a rational $p$ with $f(a)>p>a$, and

$$
f(a) \leq f(p)=p<f(a),
$$

a contradiction. Similarly if $f(a)<a$, we get a contradiction. Thus $f(x)=x$ for all $x$, the second of the two solutions to the functional equation.
informal_statement:
Find all functions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ satisfying

$$
f(x(1+y))=f(x)(1+f(y))
$$

for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Find all functions $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ satisfying

$$
f(x(1+y))=f(x)(1+f(y))
$$

for all $x, y \in \mathbb{R}$. -/
theorem algebra_253280 (f : ℝ → ℝ) :
    (∀ x y, f (x * (1 + y)) = f x * (1 + f y)) ↔
    (∀ x, f x = 0) ∨ (∀ x, f x = x) := by

soln_description:
Given that $(b, n!)=1$. By Property VII, $b$ has an inverse $b^{-1}$ modulo $n!$. We have
$$\begin{aligned}
\left(b^{-1}\right)^{n} & \cdot a(a+b) \cdots(a+(n-1) b) \\
& \equiv a b^{-1}\left(a b^{-1}+b b^{-1}\right) \cdots\left(a b^{-1}+(n-1) b b^{-1}\right) \\
& \equiv a b^{-1}\left(a b^{-1}+1\right) \cdots\left(a b^{-1}+(n-1)\right)(\bmod n!)
\end{aligned}$$

The right-hand side of the above equation is the product of $n$ consecutive integers, so by Corollary 4 of Chapter 1, § 7, we get
$$\left(b^{-1}\right)^{n} \cdot a(a+b) \cdots(a+(n-1) b \equiv 0(\bmod n!)$$

Since $\left(b^{-1}, n!\right)=1$, it follows from Property VI that
$$a(a+b) \cdots(a+(n-1) b) \equiv 0(\bmod n!)$$

This proves the desired result. Of course, this problem can also be proved without using congruence symbols; readers can try this method and will find that using congruence symbols is more concise and clear.
informal_statement: Example 5 Let $n \geqslant 1, b$ whose prime factors are all greater than $n$. Prove: for any positive integer $a$ there must be $n! \mid a(a+b)(a+2 b) \cdots(a+(n-1) b)$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 5 Let $n \geqslant 1, b$ whose prime factors are all greater than $n$. Prove: for any positive integer $a$ there must be $n! \mid a(a+b)(a+2 b) \cdots(a+(n-1) b)$ -/
theorem number_theory_6110 (n : ℕ) (hn : 1 ≤ n) (b : ℕ) (hb : ∀ p, Nat.Prime p → p ∣ b → p > n) :
    ∀ a > 0, Nat.factorial n ∣ ∏ i ∈ Finset.range n, (a + (i * b)) := by

soln_description:
$$
\text { 9. Middle } \begin{aligned}
& s^{3}\left(s^{3}-12 s r R\right)=s^{3}\left(s^{3}-3 a b c\right) \\
= & s^{3}\left[(s-a)^{3}+(s-b)^{3}+(s-c)^{3}\right] . \\
t_{a}^{2}= & \frac{4 b c}{(b+c)^{2}} s(s-a) \leqslant s(s-a) \\
& \leqslant s(s-a)+\frac{1}{4}(b-c)^{2}=m_{a}^{2} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $t_{a}^{6} \leqslant s^{3}(s-a)^{3} \leqslant m_{a}^{6}$.
informal_statement:
9. In $\triangle A B C$, prove:
$$
t_{a}^{6}+t_{b}^{6}+t_{c}^{6} \leqslant s^{4}\left(s^{2}-12 R_{r}\right) \leqslant m_{a}^{6}+m_{b}^{6}+m_{c}^{6} .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- 9. In $\triangle A B C$, prove:
$$
t_{a}^{6}+t_{b}^{6}+t_{c}^{6} \leqslant s^{4}\left(s^{2}-12 R_{r}\right) \leqslant m_{a}^{6}+m_{b}^{6}+m_{c}^{6} .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_161788 (A B C : EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2))
  (t_a t_b t_c s m_a m_b m_c R_r : ℝ)
  (ht_a : t_a = dist B C)
  (ht_b : t_b = dist A C)
  (ht_c : t_c = dist A B)
  (hs : s = (t_a + t_b + t_c) / 2)
  (hR_r : R_r > 0)
  (hm_a : m_a = dist C (midpoint ℝ A B))
  (hm_b : m_b = dist A (midpoint ℝ B C))
  (hm_c : m_c = dist B (midpoint ℝ A C)) :
  t_a^6 + t_b^6 + t_c^6 ≤ s^4 * (s^2 - 12 * R_r) ∧
  s^4 * (s^2 - 12 * R_r) ≤ m_a^6 + m_b^6 + m_c^6 :=

soln_description:
Solution. To find the limit of the given function, we will replace the argument $x$ with its limiting value:

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow 3}\left(x^{2}-7 x+4\right)=3^{2}-7 \cdot 3+4=-8
$$

theorem calculus_155065 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : f = λ x => x^2 - 7 * x + 4) :
  Tendsto f (𝓝[≠] 3) (𝓝 (-8)) :=

soln_description:
Solution. From the assumption $2 x^{2}+x=3 y^{2}+y$ it follows that

\[
\begin{aligned}
& x^{2}=x-y+3 x^{2}-3 y^{2}=(x-y)(3 x+3 y+1) \\
& y^{2}=x-y+2 x^{2}-2 y^{2}=(x-y)(2 x+2 y+1)
\end{aligned}
\]

Since the numbers $3 x+3 y+1=3(x+y)+1$ and $2 x+2 y+1=2(x+y)+1$ are coprime, then

\[
x-y=\operatorname{GCD}\left(x^{2}, y^{2}\right)=(\operatorname{GCD}(x, y))^{2}
\]

Now from equations (1) it follows that the numbers $3 x+3 y+1$ and $2 x+2 y+1$ are perfect squares.
informal_statement: 1. Let $x$ and $y$ be natural numbers such that $2 x^{2} + x = 3 y^{2} + y$. Prove that the numbers $x - y$, $2 x + 2 y + 1$, and $3 x + 3 y + 1$ are perfect squares.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Let $x$ and $y$ be natural numbers such that $2 x^{2} + x = 3 y^{2} + y$. Prove that the numbers $x - y$, $2 x + 2 y + 1$, and $3 x + 3 y + 1$ are perfect squares. -/
theorem number_theory_245049 (x y : ℕ) (h : 2 * x ^ 2 + x = 3 * y ^ 2 + y) :
    ∃ m, m ^ 2 = x - y ∧ ∃ n, n ^ 2 = 2 * x + 2 * y + 1 ∧ ∃ p, p ^ 2 = 3 * x + 3 * y + 1 := by

informal_statement: When the two-digit integer $``\text{AB}"$ is cubed, the value is $912,\!673$. What is $A + B$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- When the two-digit integer $``\text{AB}"$ is cubed, the value is $912,\!673$. What is $A + B$? -/
theorem number_theory_23252 {A B : ℕ} (h : 10 * A + B ≠ 0) (h' : (10 * A + B)^3 = 912673) :
    A + B = 16 := by

soln_description:
9.3. We shall prove that the desired number have one of the forms $9 k \pm 1$, $3^{3}(9 k \pm 1)$ or $3^{6}(9 k \pm 1)$.

Suppose that 3 does not divide $a$. Since $n^{3} \equiv 0, \pm 1(\bmod 9)$, then $a \equiv \pm 1$ $(\bmod 9)$.

Conversely, let $a \equiv \pm 1(\bmod 9)$. Since 9 divides $1^{3}-1$ and $2^{3}+1$, then there is $n_{0}$ such $n_{0}^{3}+a=3^{s} t$, where $s \geq 2$ and $t$ is not divisible by 3 . We shall prove that if $n_{1}=n_{0}+2.3^{s-1} t$, then $3^{s+1}$ divides $n_{1}^{3}+a$. We have that

$$
\left(n_{0}+2.3^{s-1} t\right)^{3}+a=3^{s} t\left(2 n_{0}^{2}+1\right)+4 n_{0} 3^{2 s-1} t^{2}+8.3^{3 s-3} t^{3}
$$

Since 3 does not divide $n_{0}$, then $2 n_{0}^{2}+1$ is divisible by 3 . Moreover, $2 s-1 \geq s+1$ and $3 s-3 \geq s+1$. Hence $n_{1}^{3}+a$ is divisible by $3^{s+1}$ but 3 does not divide $n_{1}$. Repeating the same argument, we get a positive integer $n_{p}$ such that $3^{2003}$ divides $n_{p}^{3}+a$.

Let now 3 divides $a<2003$. Then $a=3^{s} b$, where $s \leq 6$. Hence $n$ is divisible by 3 , i.e., $n=3^{p} n_{0}$, where $p \geq 1$ and 3 does not divide $n_{0}$. If $p \geq 3$, then $3^{9}$ divides $n^{3}$ and does not divide $a$ which implies that $3^{2003}$ does not divide $n^{3}+a$. Hence $p=1$ or $p=2$ and it is easy to see that $s=3$ or $s=6$, respectively.

In the first case we get that $3^{2000}$ divides $n_{0}^{3}+b$, where 3 does not divide $b$ and $27 b<2003$. It follows as above that $b \equiv \pm 1(\bmod 9)$.

In the second case we get similarly that $3^{1997}$ divides $n_{0}^{3}+b$, where $729 b<$ 2003 and $b \equiv \pm 1(\bmod 9)$.

The number of the positive integers $b \equiv \pm 1(\bmod 9)$ such that $b<2003$, $27 b<2003$ or $729 b<2003$ equals $2.222+1=445,2.8+1=17$ or 1 , respectively. Hence the desired number is equal to $445+17+1=463$.
informal_statement:
Problem 9.3. Find the number of positive integers $a$ less than 2003 , for which there exists a positive integer $n$ such that $3^{2003}$ divides $n^{3}+a$.

Emil Kolev, Nikolai Nikolov
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Problem 9.3. Find the number of positive integers $a$ less than 2003 , for which there exists a positive integer $n$ such that $3^{2003}$ divides $n^{3}+a$.

Emil Kolev, Nikolai Nikolov -/
theorem number_theory_295954 :
    Set.ncard {a : ℕ | 0 < a ∧ a < 2003 ∧ ∃ n : ℕ, 0 < n ∧ 3^2003 ∣ n^3 + a} = 463 := by

informal_statement:
3. $a, b, c$ are real numbers, and $a^{2}-b c-8 a+7=0$, $b^{2}+c^{2}+b c-6 a+6=0$. Then the range of values for $a$ is ( ).
(A) $-\infty1$.
(C) $1<a<13$.
(D) $1 \leqslant a \leqslant 9$.
informal_proof:
Let $a$, $b$, and $c$ be real numbers such that $a^2 - bc - 8a + 7 = 0$ and $b^2 + c^2 + bc - 6a + 6 = 0$.

From the algebraic inequality $(b - c)^2 \geq 0$, we have $b^2 - 2bc + c^2 \geq 0$, which implies $b^2 + c^2 \geq 2bc$.

The second given equation can be rewritten as $b^2 + c^2 + bc = 6a - 6$.

Adding $bc$ to both sides of the inequality $b^2 + c^2 \geq 2bc$, we get $b^2 + c^2 + bc \geq 2bc + bc$, which simplifies to $b^2 + c^2 + bc \geq 3bc$.

Substituting $6a - 6$ for $b^2 + c^2 + bc$, we obtain $6a - 6 \geq 3bc$.

From the first given equation, $a^2 - bc - 8a + 7 = 0$, we can express $bc$ as $bc = a^2 - 8a + 7$.

Substituting this expression for $bc$ into the inequality $6a - 6 \geq 3bc$, we get:
$6a - 6 \geq 3(a^2 - 8a + 7)$

Expanding the right side, we have:
$6a - 6 \geq 3a^2 - 24a + 21$

Rearranging the terms to one side to form a quadratic inequality in $a$:
$0 \geq 3a^2 - 24a - 6a + 21 + 6$
$0 \geq 3a^2 - 30a + 27$

Dividing the inequality by 3 yields:
$0 \geq a^2 - 10a + 9$

Factoring the quadratic expression $a^2 - 10a + 9$, we get $(a - 1)(a - 9)$. Thus, the inequality is $(a - 1)(a - 9) \leq 0$.

This inequality holds if and only if $a$ lies between the roots $1$ and $9$, inclusive. Therefore, $1 \leq a \leq 9$.

This means the range of values for $a$ is the closed interval $[1, 9]$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3. $a, b, c$ are real numbers, and $a^{2}-b c-8 a+7=0$, $b^{2}+c^{2}+b c-6 a+6=0$. Then the range of values for $a$ is ( ).
(A) $-\infty1$.
(C) $1<a<13$.
(D) $1 \leqslant a \leqslant 9$. -/
theorem algebra_322835 (a b c : ℝ)
    (h₀ : a^2 - b * c - 8 * a + 7 = 0) (h₁ : b^2 + c^2 + b * c - 6 * a + 6 = 0) :
    1 ≤ a ∧ a ≤ 9 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_322835 (a b c : ℝ)
    (h₀ : a^2 - b * c - 8 * a + 7 = 0) (h₁ : b^2 + c^2 + b * c - 6 * a + 6 = 0) :
    1 ≤ a ∧ a ≤ 9 := by

  have h2 : b^2 + c^2 ≥ 2 * (b * c) := by 
    linarith [sq_nonneg (b - c)]

  have h3 : b^2 + c^2 + b * c = 6 * a - 6 := by
    linarith

  have h4 : 6 * a - 6 ≥ 3 * (b * c) := by 
    nlinarith [h2, h3]

  have h5 : b * c = a^2 - 8 * a + 7 := by 
    linarith

  have h6 : 2 * a - 2 ≥ a^2 - 8 * a + 7 := by 
    nlinarith [h4, h5]

  have h7 : a^2 - 10 * a + 9 ≤ 0 := by 
    nlinarith

  constructor
  · -- Prove 1 ≤ a
    nlinarith 
  · -- Prove a ≤ 9
    nlinarith

soln_description:
Let $\sqrt{2^{x-1}}=X$, $\sqrt{3 y+1}=Y$, obviously we have $X>0$, $\boldsymbol{Y}>0$.

Then the original equation can be transformed into
$$
\frac{36}{X}+\frac{4}{Y}+4 X+Y=28 .
$$
(1) can be rewritten as
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\left(2 \sqrt{X}-\frac{6}{2 \bar{X}}\right)^{2} \\
+\left(\sqrt{Y}-\frac{2}{\sqrt{Y}}\right)^{2}=0 .
\end{array}
$$

From (2) we get
$$
2 v \bar{X}-\frac{\beta}{\sqrt{X}}=0
$$

and $\checkmark \bar{Y}-\frac{2}{\sqrt{Y}}=0$.
$$
\therefore \quad X=3, \quad Y=2 \text {. }
$$

Thus, $\sqrt{2 x-1}=3, \sqrt{3 y+1}=2$.
$$
\therefore x=5, \quad y=1 \text {. }
$$

Therefore, the real solutions to the original equation are
$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
x=5, \\
y=1 .
\end{array}\right.
$$
informal_statement:
Example 6. Find the real solutions of the equation
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{36}{\sqrt{2 x-1}}+\frac{4}{\sqrt{3 y+1}} \\
+4 \sqrt{2 x-1}+\sqrt{3 y+1}=28
\end{array}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 6. Find the real solutions of the equation
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{36}{\sqrt{2 x-1}}+\frac{4}{\sqrt{3 y+1}} \\
+4 \sqrt{2 x-1}+\sqrt{3 y+1}=28
\end{array}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_316812 (x y : ℝ) (hx : x ≥ 1 / 2) (hy : y ≥ -1 / 3)
    (h : 36 / Real.sqrt (2 * x - 1) + 4 / Real.sqrt (3 * y + 1) +
      4 * Real.sqrt (2 * x - 1) + Real.sqrt (3 * y + 1) = 28) :
    x = 5 ∧ y = 1 := by
